Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Learning About Complex Causality in the Classroom

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Dealing with the world's most pressing problems requires an ability to understand and reason about causal complexity. For instance, understanding topics such as ecosystems and global warming involves reasoning about non-obvious causes, spatial gaps, temporal delays, cyclic causality, and distributed causality where the agency/intentionality of one's actions is on a different level than those of the emergent outcomes. The focus of this proposal is on how children learn to reason about complex causality and how that reasoning can be stimulated and taught in classrooms. The literature on child development suggests that children are capable of understanding complex causal concepts to a greater extent than earlier research suggested. Yet, paradoxically, students' misconceptions in science have been linked to students' difficulties reasoning about complex causality. This study will explore how children learn to reason when provided with activities and materials that support three types of reasoning: distributed causality, probabilistic causality, and action at a distance. By conducting and videotaping close interviews at multiple points in the school year with small numbers of students in grades K-6 (the microgenetic phase), the study will characterize children's reasoning at different ages and how it shifts over time and with different learning supports. It will consider the contexts of biology, mechanical reasoning, social reasoning, and games. Classroom-level interventions will then be introduced and studied. In the last year of the project, using what was learned about children's reasoning and how to support it, ecosystems and global warming curriculum units will be designed and tested in a larger number of classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CAREER: Learning about Causal Complexity in the Classroom

Understanding the natural world and the dynamics that lead to changes in ecosystems, climate, and other environmental systems involves being able to reason about features of causality that involve considerable complexity. This project studied three features of causality that are important to understanding such systems. The first, called action at an attentional distance, considers cases in which causes and effects are separate in space and time so that it is difficult to notice a correlation between them and subsequently to evaluate whether they are causally connected.  The second, called distributed causality, considers cases in which the actions of many actors are distributed over space and time and have a collective or synergistic effect, often unintended, that the actors have a hard time noticing and feeling responsibility for. The third, probabilistic causality, considers the statistical nature between causes and effects and how summing over time may lead us to notice a connection, but often intervening space and time make it just as likely that we will fail to notice a possible relationship.

Learning how to reason about causality in each of these instances is very important to growing up in a complex world. There is little focus on causal reasoning in most classrooms.  However, the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) call for a greater focus on causal reasoning and systems thinking. Further, despite their challenges, each of these causal features arise in everyday experience. This raises the question of how we can use students' experiences to help them build understanding of the complex forms in nature.

The first phase of the project investigated what experiences and knowledge children typically hold about each of these causal features and how we might leverage it towards greater understanding. Working with kindergarteners, second, fourth, and sixth graders, we studied instances in classroom life when children interacted with these concepts. Then we conducted in-depth interviews and developed instructional supports. We used a set of tasks that were familiar to children—games, planting seeds, noise in the cafeteria, etc. We studied each of the concepts across an entire year to see what students understood initially and what they could learn at each grade level with opportunities and instruction designed to support them. 

The results of the first phase showed that even kindergarteners revealed a greater grasp of the concepts than previously thought. For probabilistic causation, students at each grade level were able to learn to recognize instances when causes did not reliably lead to effects and to adjust their predictions and strategies to account for the lack of one to one correspondence. For action at an attentional distance, students were able to accept distant causes and effects if they held the relevant mechanism knowledge to connect the two. For distributed causality, students did not default towards centralized causal agents to the extent expected based upon earlier research and learned to recognize that collective and emergent outcomes are possible.

In the second phase of the project, we developed and tested Causal Learning in the Classroom (CLiC) curriculum modules to teach reasoning about each causal feature in the context of environmental concepts.  We worked with a total of 682 students and 19 teachers from nine schools representing diverse ethnic, racial, and SES populations and a range of school types.
